fullProgramDescription: The Bachelor of Science in Chemistry is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental principles of chemistry. The program includes coursework in inorganic, organic, physical, and analytical chemistry, as well as laboratory research experiences. Students develop skills in data analysis, problem-solving, and scientific communication. The program prepares students for careers in research, industry, and education, as well as for graduate study in chemistry or related fields.
shortProgramDescription: The Chemistry B.S. program at UC San Diego provides a rigorous foundation in chemistry and prepares students for careers or further study.
classHighlights: The chemistry core curriculum includes courses in General Chemistry (CHEM6A-B-C), Organic Chemistry (CHEM41A-B-C), Physical Chemistry (CHEM130A-B), and Analytical Chemistry (CHEM171).
Students also complete laboratory courses, including General Chemistry Laboratory (CHEM7L), Organic Chemistry Laboratory (CHEM43A-B), and Physical Chemistry Laboratory (CHEM131L).
Additional required courses include Inorganic Chemistry (CHEM141), Biochemistry (CHEM163), and Chemistry Laboratory Safety (CHEM195).

Electives in advanced chemistry topics, such as Advanced Organic Chemistry (CHEM144), Advanced Physical Chemistry (CHEM132), and Special Topics in Chemistry (CHEM199), allow students to explore specialized areas.
The program also includes a capstone experience through laboratory research or a senior thesis.
learningOutcomes: Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental principles of chemistry.
Apply chemical knowledge to solve problems and analyze data.
Communicate scientific information effectively in written and oral forms.
Design and conduct experiments, including data collection and analysis.
Understand and apply laboratory safety protocols and procedures.
Evaluate and interpret scientific literature and research.
additionalInformation: Students must complete a minimum of180 units, including major requirements and upper-division coursework. GPA requirements and grading policies apply. Research opportunities and internships are available.
